guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

body:
Different translations speak to me differently. I think the bible is the most direct way to understand Christ, but it needs more than surface level to truly understand it. 

While to me, the bible (The word) is the ultimate authority over how I should live my life, I understand it's interpretation can be wildly vast, and Christ's presence in the bible steers that ship.

body:
They're both reductionist perspectives. You do need an authoritative hierarchy, but it can't be the Bible. At least, not on its own, because it's not conscious. You can twist the Bible's arm to make it say whatever you want, there has to be a socially corrective mechanism in place.

That's why Jesus and his Apostles gave us the Church, not the Bible.

But it can't be entirely order either, because the institution is also wrong all the time, it's just less wrong than you are ("you" being pretty much every individual, not You.)

body:
I believe Christ will guide you either way if you truly want guidance without ever having read the bible BUT there is wisdom from those who came before us contained within that book that will indeed make this battle all the easier. We should commune with one another and learn from the wisdom & experiences of our forbearers while also remembering only Yeshua our Christ is ultimately the only one who lived an entirely blameless life before the eyes of man and God. He was killed for this and for disputing the Pharisees who continued adding to God's word by burdening His people with more & more laws of their own design.

As you said, YHWH and Yeshua are the authority in your life, take your questions to them and I believe you will find your answers even if they may not make much much sense at first.

You'd know about Jesus through the Church. That's how it always worked.

Weird verse to justify such a claim with, too. All that claims is that people know truth when they hear it, it's got nothing to do with the Bible. The Bible wouldn't even exist until hundreds of years later.

body:
This is some crazy selective interpretation, man.

The Torah was memorized often, so fair enough on that one. But when do you think the printing press was invented? lol No one had a Bible until about the time of the Reformation. Parishes had Bibles, but by in large, people did not. It would be virtually impossible to acquire one.

The current canon was written within living memory of Jesus (with a few contested cases, but I don't think those are important) but they were not compiled at scale for many hundreds of years, and often times the books being used went beyond the ones we have today. It's easy to read the Church Fathers and assume they're an objective party in retrospect, but to the lay person of the time? No, there was no clear Bible. There was *especially* no clear New Testament, and even after there was, it took a thousand years for anyone to know about it except privileged intellectuals.

The Bible is not meant to be read by most people. That's simply not compatible with the context in which it arose. The living body of Christ is the Church, the Bible is a tool of the Church, and a damn good one. But it is fundamentally a tool, not a foundation.

body:
You are right about one thing, that there was no set criteria on what made up the Bible for thousands of years. But I've got news for you, there STILL isn't a consensus today. Just look at the orthodox church with it's official Bible that includes many more books than western Bibles.

But that's not the point. The original premise of OP's post was that the Bible is unnecessary and that Jesus alone is enough. But that is false.

The reason i used that faith verse is to highlight the main point of the Bible. It is God's chosen method to deliver the Gospel - the same thing Jesus told the disciples right before he left. When Paul taught the Thessalonians the Gospel in Acts 17, it says that they searched the scriptures daily. Why would they need to if Jesus was enough?

Do you remember the Ethiopian in Acts 8:27? He was reading the Torah and Philip told him about Jesus using the passage he was reading. Clearly this is a mistake since the Torah is useless and Jesus is enough.

The Torah Is the Bible and the King James is also the Bible because the Bible IS the Word of God, and by hearing the Word of God we have faith. It's not useless.

Also, to answer the Bible question, just because the Dark ages had a distinct lack of literate people and copies of the Bible, doesn't mean the rest of the thousand years were the same. We have manuscripts of the original Gospels going back to the first century. Even Wikipedia admits that much.

https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biblical_manuscript

And we also have compilations of Bibles going back to near the time of Christ. Just look at this Ethiopian Bible. Dont you think that if the Ethiopians had a version of a Bible, that the Hebrews and Greeks and Romans might have one also?

https://orthochristian.com/94812.html

Don't assume that just because you're an enlightened 21st century intellectual, that all people living before you were idiots. People are smart, even back then. If they see something that looks like the Gods Word, they will hold on to it and pass it along.

body:
>But I've got news for you, there STILL isn't a consensus today. Just look at the orthodox church with it's official Bible that includes many more books than western Bibles.

Yeah, my Bible has all those books, even the really obscure ones that weren't in the old Vulgate. You realize they don't actually use those books for liturgy though, right? It's not even a matter of official canonization, they're just traditionally there because that's how the domino fell. It's not a serious problem, the only genuine canonical disagreements are between Roman Catholics and Protestants, which is more political than anything. It's all Old Testament too, the scriptures that universally apply to us aren't disputed by anyone.

If you ask an English speaking Orthodox Christian which translation they read, there's a good chance it's just the King James or another popular Protestant Bible. It's really not that important for the original Christians.

>But that's not the point. The original premise of OP's post was that the Bible is unnecessary and that Jesus alone is enough. But that is false.

You're ignoring the reality of the printing press innovation, which proves him right.

>The reason i used that faith verse is to highlight the main point of the Bible. It is God's chosen method to deliver the Gospel - the same thing Jesus told the disciples right before he left. When Paul taught the Thessalonians the Gospel in Acts 17, it says that they searched the scriptures daily. Why would they need to if Jesus was enough?

You used it incorrectly, and Acts 17 is referring to a group at a Synagogue. They would have community scriptures, of the Torah if nothing else. This was at the height of the Roman Empire, by the way, where literacy was at a peak, that period lasted for an extremely brief time. There's also the fact that the entire Jewish faith was destroyed in 70 AD, it had relevance then that it doesn't now. There's a group of Eastern Europeans that call themselves Orthodox Jews, but it's name only, their practice and beliefs have little in common with the 2nd Temple Judaism that was practiced in New Testament times.

>Do you remember the Ethiopian in Acts 8:27? He was reading the Torah and Philip told him about Jesus using the passage he was reading. Clearly this is a mistake since the Torah is useless and Jesus is enough.

Silly objection. No one will say the old scriptures aren't useful. No one will even say they aren't necessary. But are they alone an absolute authority on how to live? No, that responsibility has always been left to the Church. Your opinion is virtually unprecedented in Christian history.

>just because the Dark ages had a distinct lack of literate people and copies of the Bible, doesn't mean the rest of the thousand years were the same. We have manuscripts of the original Gospels going back to the first century.

There actually aren't any useful manuscripts going back that far. There are some from the 2nd Century though.

Literacy was not anywhere near universal until the past 200-ish years. You'd expect there to be a lot of manuscripts, there were lots of parishes. The Church got pretty big. That doesn't mean everyone can read it, virtually no one could just come in and handle it, even on the off chance they were literate. It was a tool of privilege. Unless you believe only literate agents of the Church and maybe some kids of wealthy parents can enter the Kingdom of God, you absolutely have to make this concession. Christ himself spent most of his Earthly ministry preaching the exact opposite.

You could say that it's necessary now that we have it. But you'd have a hard time sourcing it, and I can think of a lot of good reasons why lay people shouldn't *cough* Scofield *cough.*

>Don't assume ... that all people living before you were idiots. People are smart, even back then. If they see something that looks like the Gods Word, they will hold on to it and pass it along.

I explicitly do not think that, but the way you are conveying this is simply a lie. That's not how it happened. It's probably not an intentional lie on your part, you probably legitimately don't know, or were mislead. But people did not "hold onto" or "pass on" the "Word of God." It was preserved institutionally, by the one Universal, Apostolic Church that was founded by Christ and his Apostles.

Also, to answer the Bible question, just because the Dark ages had a distinct lack of literate people and copies of the Bible, doesn't mean the rest of the thousand years were the same. We have manuscripts of the original Gospels going back to the first century. Even Wikipedia admits that much.

https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biblical_manuscript

And we also have compilations of Bibles going back to near the time of Christ. Just look at this Ethiopian Bible. Dont you think that if the Ethiopians had a version of a Bible, that the Hebrews and Greeks and Romans might have one also?

https://orthochristian.com/94812.html

Don't assume that just because you're an enlightened 21st century intellectual, that all people living before you were idiots. People are smart, even back then. If they see something that looks like the Gods Word, they will hold on to it and pass it along.

post.body: The authors of the Bible, the Nicean Council, Martin Luther, Scofield, etc... have no authority over me, Christ does - He alone is the word of God.

body:
I think i will concede most of that. I think you are right that most of the time the Word is passed on by someone telling it to someone else, like a pastor to the congregation. My weak counter would be that he would either have needed to memorize the scriptures himself, or have scriptures on hand (complete or not).

I apologize for any hash words in above posts. The Bible is precious in my circle because I come from a background where my family was persecuted for even owning scraps of the Bible, and so I felt the need to defend it.

Rereading OP's post, one counter to another aspect is that the individual church is given authority to do things like excommunicate if necessary or set rules. So if OP is part of a church, not only is he under the authority of Jesus, but also under the authority of the church.

I know churches with all sorts of weird rules, but i'm pretty sure it's their right to set it. I think it was Corinthians that had a head coverings rule, and Paul reiterated that it was a valid rule. I think it's also valid to use the scriptures as a basis to set rules. As you said, it's a pretty good tool.

parent.body:
>But I've got news for you, there STILL isn't a consensus today. Just look at the orthodox church with it's official Bible that includes many more books than western Bibles.

Yeah, my Bible has all those books, even the really obscure ones that weren't in the old Vulgate. You realize they don't actually use those books for liturgy though, right? It's not even a matter of official canonization, they're just traditionally there because that's how the domino fell. It's not a serious problem, the only genuine canonical disagreements are between Roman Catholics and Protestants, which is more political than anything. It's all Old Testament too, the scriptures that universally apply to us aren't disputed by anyone.

If you ask an English speaking Orthodox Christian which translation they read, there's a good chance it's just the King James or another popular Protestant Bible. It's really not that important for the original Christians.

>But that's not the point. The original premise of OP's post was that the Bible is unnecessary and that Jesus alone is enough. But that is false.

You're ignoring the reality of the printing press innovation, which proves him right.

>The reason i used that faith verse is to highlight the main point of the Bible. It is God's chosen method to deliver the Gospel - the same thing Jesus told the disciples right before he left. When Paul taught the Thessalonians the Gospel in Acts 17, it says that they searched the scriptures daily. Why would they need to if Jesus was enough?

You used it incorrectly, and Acts 17 is referring to a group at a Synagogue. They would have community scriptures, of the Torah if nothing else. This was at the height of the Roman Empire, by the way, where literacy was at a peak, that period lasted for an extremely brief time. There's also the fact that the entire Jewish faith was destroyed in 70 AD, it had relevance then that it doesn't now. There's a group of Eastern Europeans that call themselves Orthodox Jews, but it's name only, their practice and beliefs have little in common with the 2nd Temple Judaism that was practiced in New Testament times.

>Do you remember the Ethiopian in Acts 8:27? He was reading the Torah and Philip told him about Jesus using the passage he was reading. Clearly this is a mistake since the Torah is useless and Jesus is enough.

Silly objection. No one will say the old scriptures aren't useful. No one will even say they aren't necessary. But are they alone an absolute authority on how to live? No, that responsibility has always been left to the Church. Your opinion is virtually unprecedented in Christian history.

>just because the Dark ages had a distinct lack of literate people and copies of the Bible, doesn't mean the rest of the thousand years were the same. We have manuscripts of the original Gospels going back to the first century.

There actually aren't any useful manuscripts going back that far. There are some from the 2nd Century though.

Literacy was not anywhere near universal until the past 200-ish years. You'd expect there to be a lot of manuscripts, there were lots of parishes. The Church got pretty big. That doesn't mean everyone can read it, virtually no one could just come in and handle it, even on the off chance they were literate. It was a tool of privilege. Unless you believe only literate agents of the Church and maybe some kids of wealthy parents can enter the Kingdom of God, you absolutely have to make this concession. Christ himself spent most of his Earthly ministry preaching the exact opposite.

You could say that it's necessary now that we have it. But you'd have a hard time sourcing it, and I can think of a lot of good reasons why lay people shouldn't *cough* Scofield *cough.*

>Don't assume ... that all people living before you were idiots. People are smart, even back then. If they see something that looks like the Gods Word, they will hold on to it and pass it along.

I explicitly do not think that, but the way you are conveying this is simply a lie. That's not how it happened. It's probably not an intentional lie on your part, you probably legitimately don't know, or were mislead. But people did not "hold onto" or "pass on" the "Word of God." It was preserved institutionally, by the one Universal, Apostolic Church that was founded by Christ and his Apostles.

body:
It's fine.

There is the problem that, well, you give the Church authority, okay. So which Church? All Churches? Well no, probably not. Most Christians wouldn't take the Latter Day Saints or Jehovah's Witnesses seriously.

And then, if you do figure that out, what do you do when the ones you pickes are wrong, as they almost certainly will be. It almost sounds pedantic, but those are serious questions! When you don't solve them, you get lunatics like like Scofield and Joseph Smith who take massive chunks out of the real Christian movements.

I don't have objective answers for problems of Church authority, it's an issue I'm struggling with, but the Scriptures are where you want to go when things have self-evidently gone terribly wrong. as did happen several times in Roman Catholic history, for example, and the result was Lutheranism. I'm not writing the Bible off by any means, it's incredibly important, but it was never meant to be the end-all be-all of everything.

parent.body:
They had the law in the Torah. You remember this passage?

Luke 24:27 And beginning at Moses and all the prophets, he expounded unto them in all the scriptures the things concerning himself.

Clearly the Torah was enough.

But even then, where do you get this "didnt have a Bible" nonsense? Yes the King James was created then, but all of those texts existed since the 1st Century.

All of the current cannon books were written within 100 years of the death of Jesus. I think it was Luke that was written even within 30 years. And so people had all of these writings to reference.

>When Paul taught the Thessalonians the Gospel in Acts 17, it says that they searched the scriptures daily. Why would they need to if Jesus was enough?

Ironic. If they searched the scripture they wouldn't follow Paul, and if Christians searched their scripture they wouldn't be Christians.

parent.body:
You are right about one thing, that there was no set criteria on what made up the Bible for thousands of years. But I've got news for you, there STILL isn't a consensus today. Just look at the orthodox church with it's official Bible that includes many more books than western Bibles.

But that's not the point. The original premise of OP's post was that the Bible is unnecessary and that Jesus alone is enough. But that is false.

The reason i used that faith verse is to highlight the main point of the Bible. It is God's chosen method to deliver the Gospel - the same thing Jesus told the disciples right before he left. When Paul taught the Thessalonians the Gospel in Acts 17, it says that they searched the scriptures daily. Why would they need to if Jesus was enough?

Do you remember the Ethiopian in Acts 8:27? He was reading the Torah and Philip told him about Jesus using the passage he was reading. Clearly this is a mistake since the Torah is useless and Jesus is enough.

The Torah Is the Bible and the King James is also the Bible because the Bible IS the Word of God, and by hearing the Word of God we have faith. It's not useless.

Also, to answer the Bible question, just because the Dark ages had a distinct lack of literate people and copies of the Bible, doesn't mean the rest of the thousand years were the same. We have manuscripts of the original Gospels going back to the first century. Even Wikipedia admits that much.

https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biblical_manuscript

And we also have compilations of Bibles going back to near the time of Christ. Just look at this Ethiopian Bible. Dont you think that if the Ethiopians had a version of a Bible, that the Hebrews and Greeks and Romans might have one also?

https://orthochristian.com/94812.html

Don't assume that just because you're an enlightened 21st century intellectual, that all people living before you were idiots. People are smart, even back then. If they see something that looks like the Gods Word, they will hold on to it and pass it along.

body:
Do you have examples of the NT contradicting the OT? Or Paul contradicting Jesus? I'd like to see them.

Your last claim is a straw man argument. You don't need to understand scripture to be a Christian. Many people dont and yet they still trust in the Grace that Jesus freely gives them, and he freely gives that Grace to you also if you are willing to accept it.

Also, even if half of the Bible is false, it doesn't disprove Gods existence. All it proves is that people are terrible at being truthful and terrible at record keeping (both debatable).

Finally, by your logic, if i don't understand Newton's or Einstein's theories of gravity, then i cant be a believer in them. After all, Newton and Einstien came up with flawed theories for gravity, and yet they accurately represent the world around us. I can believe in their relative accuracy.

post.title: Some of the Churches I have visited recently have said that the Bible is the authority in my life

body:
I claim no authority on the Bible. God himself claims the Bible as authoritative, Jesus claims the Torah as authoritative, and the writers of the NT claimed Gods authority as well. For example:

Jeremiah 30:2
Thus speaketh the LORD God of Israel, saying, Write thee all the words that I have spoken unto thee in a book.

John 15:25
But this cometh to pass, that the word might be fulfilled that is written in their law (Jesus talking)

1 Thessalonians 2:13
For this cause also thank we God without ceasing, because, when ye received the word of God which ye heard of us, ye received it not as the word of men, but as it is in truth, the word of God

Revelation 1:1-2
The Revelation of Jesus Christ, which God gave unto him, to shew unto his servants things which must shortly come to pass; and he sent and signified it by his angel unto his servant John: who bare record of the word of God, and of the testimony of Jesus Christ, and of all things that he saw.

I'm sure with a bit of searching you could find more passages.

I have some questions for you if you want to answer them. If God is real, why wouldn't He direct people to write down what He said? Why wouldn't He attempt to keep His word pure? Why wouldn't He inspire groups of people to purge false documents from it? Is He that weak of a God that He would allow His Word to be corrupted?

Take this analogy. If a government wants to institute a new speed limit on a road, they need to announce the new law, put up a sign with the new speed limit on it, and then replace the sign if it gets damaged. Same with God. He announced His Law, then gave the people the Law who wrote it down, and then He preserved it.

body:
>God himself claims the Bible as authoritative

No, that's a filthy, disgusting lie. Which canon would even that be? The 66 book canon, the 73 book canon, Luther's canon, the 81 boin canon, Marcion's canon? Who compiled and canonized it for you? Who titled the gospels? Who commended you to falsely assert it to be God's word? 

>Take this analogy. If a government wants to institute a new speed limit on a road, they need to announce the new law, put up a sign with the new speed limit on it, and then replace the sign if it gets damaged. Same with God. He announced His Law, then gave the people the Law who wrote it down, and then He preserved it.

Which people would that be and preserve what? Do you even understand the absolute irony of that analogy. Christianity is a satanic, idolatrous, pagan perversion and inversion of the Hebraic religion it claims to fullfill. And your own scripture literally bears witness against you. 

>1 Thessalonians 2:13

Once again, the absolute irony. You're quoting the letters of Paul to communicaties and persons intended to be claiming to be "God's word". It gets even worse when you realize Paul was a false apostle, fake Pharisee, and even worse still when you realize the Bible contains disputed, inauthentic Pauline epistels too. So who compiled and canonized that for you? Who promoted it to "God's word"?
body_html:
God himself claims the Bible as authoritative

No, that's a filthy, disgusting lie. Which canon would even that be? The 66 book canon, the 73 book canon, Luther's canon, the 81 boin canon, Marcion's canon? Who compiled and canonized it for you? Who titled the gospels? Who commended you to falsely assert it to be God's word?

Take this analogy. If a government wants to institute a new speed limit on a road, they need to announce the new law, put up a sign with the new speed limit on it, and then replace the sign if it gets damaged. Same with God. He announced His Law, then gave the people the Law who wrote it down, and then He preserved it.

Which people would that be and preserve what? Do you even understand the absolute irony of that analogy. Christianity is a satanic, idolatrous, pagan perversion and inversion of the Hebraic religion it claims to fullfill. And your own scripture literally bears witness against you.

1 Thessalonians 2:13

Once again, the absolute irony. You're quoting the letters of Paul to communicaties and persons intended to be claiming to be "God's word". It gets even worse when you realize Paul was a false apostle, fake Pharisee, and even worse still when you realize the Bible contains disputed, inauthentic Pauline epistels too. So who compiled and canonized that for you? Who promoted it to "God's word"?

parent.body:
Do you have examples of the NT contradicting the OT? Or Paul contradicting Jesus? I'd like to see them.

Your last claim is a straw man argument. You don't need to understand scripture to be a Christian. Many people dont and yet they still trust in the Grace that Jesus freely gives them, and he freely gives that Grace to you also if you are willing to accept it.

Also, even if half of the Bible is false, it doesn't disprove Gods existence. All it proves is that people are terrible at being truthful and terrible at record keeping (both debatable).

Finally, by your logic, if i don't understand Newton's or Einstein's theories of gravity, then i cant be a believer in them. After all, Newton and Einstien came up with flawed theories for gravity, and yet they accurately represent the world around us. I can believe in their relative accuracy.

body:
I can now see the angle you are coming from. I just replied to the other chain and realized that you are the same person replying here.

I would strongly recommend you read Isaiah 53, and compare that to the life of Jesus.

The Torah is indeed Gods Word to the people and especially to the people of Israel, and I would just like to remind you of a couple of moments.

1. God promised Eve that a man would be born from her that would bruise the head of the serpent.

2. David in psalms 110 prophesied about a Lord that would overcome.

3. Isaiah 53, the prophesy of a coming savior that would cover the sins of mankind.

So when do you think the savior will show up? He was prophesied about all throughout the Torah, and if not Jesus then who?

Once again, the absolute irony. You're quoting the letters of Paul to communicaties and persons intended to be claiming to be "God's word". body:
I looked up the first messianic prophecy and its the one where Jesus resurrected. Well, here are some proofs.

1. Jesus was dead. The soldier poked his side with a spear and water came out showing his lungs had filled with water.

2. The pharisees set up professional guards around the tomb and rolled a big boulder in front of it. A bunch of scared disciples wouldn't have been able to do much about them.

3. The body of Jesus is missing. If He didn't resurrect, where is the body?

4. None of the disciples admitted to stealing the body and none ever gave a location for the body even under intense torture. Who would willingly get tortured for a lie?

5. The pharisees did not kill the soldiers for failing their mission. This was standard practice and yet they were instead given money and told to spread the story that the disciples stole the body.

6. If the disciples actually did steal the body, the soldiers would have been killed and an immediate massive search would have started for the disciples and body of Jesus. There was no extensive search.

7. Jesus reportedly appeared to many people in Jerusalem after his supposed resurrection. All of those people then became witnesses, and none of them denied seeing Him.

At best, you can say that you don't think He resurrected. Without a body, you cannot say that He for sure didn't resurrect.

As for Paul, the burden of proof is on you. Do some research and prove how Paul "Perverted the Hebrew Bible"

body:
Genesis 1:26
And God said, Let us make man in our image, after our likeness

Why "our" likeness and not "my" likeness?

Deuteronomy 6:4
Hear, O Israel: The LORD our God is one

"One" in Deuteronomy is using the Hebrew word ekhad (אֶדחָֽ) which means "unity"

Rewritten:
Hear, O Israel: The LORD our God is unity.

How would you explain both of these passages from the Torah?

Deuteronomy 6:4
Hear, O Israel: The LORD our God is one

"One" in Deuteronomy is using the Hebrew word ekhad (אֶדחָֽ) which means "unity"

Rewritten:
Hear, O Israel: The LORD our God is unity.

How would you explain both of these passages from the Torah?

parent.body:
I looked up the first messianic prophecy and its the one where Jesus resurrected. Well, here are some proofs.

1. Jesus was dead. The soldier poked his side with a spear and water came out showing his lungs had filled with water.

2. The pharisees set up professional guards around the tomb and rolled a big boulder in front of it. A bunch of scared disciples wouldn't have been able to do much about them.

3. The body of Jesus is missing. If He didn't resurrect, where is the body?

4. None of the disciples admitted to stealing the body and none ever gave a location for the body even under intense torture. Who would willingly get tortured for a lie?

5. The pharisees did not kill the soldiers for failing their mission. This was standard practice and yet they were instead given money and told to spread the story that the disciples stole the body.

6. If the disciples actually did steal the body, the soldiers would have been killed and an immediate massive search would have started for the disciples and body of Jesus. There was no extensive search.

7. Jesus reportedly appeared to many people in Jerusalem after his supposed resurrection. All of those people then became witnesses, and none of them denied seeing Him.

At best, you can say that you don't think He resurrected. Without a body, you cannot say that He for sure didn't resurrect.

As for Paul, the burden of proof is on you. Do some research and prove how Paul "Perverted the Hebrew Bible"

parent.body:
I can now see the angle you are coming from. I just replied to the other chain and realized that you are the same person replying here.

I would strongly recommend you read Isaiah 53, and compare that to the life of Jesus.

The Torah is indeed Gods Word to the people and especially to the people of Israel, and I would just like to remind you of a couple of moments.

1. God promised Eve that a man would be born from her that would bruise the head of the serpent.

2. David in psalms 110 prophesied about a Lord that would overcome.

3. Isaiah 53, the prophesy of a coming savior that would cover the sins of mankind.

So when do you think the savior will show up? He was prophesied about all throughout the Torah, and if not Jesus then who?

body:
Mathew 1:23 which is referencing Isaiah 7:14.

Well, if you think that it's impossible that a virgin can give birth, then you must also believe that this Isaiah prophesy is wrong, which would mean the Torah is corrupt. If you think virgin birth is possible, then why not Jesus? We know Joseph isn't his father, so...

This is the first time im hearing about lo-ammi, but what i can gather from google is that its a period of time where God rejects the Isreal people and deals with all nations. I'm not sure, but that seems to support Paul in his claim that it's now the time of the gentiles, unless im missing something.

That he was in conflict with Jerusalem means nothing. All people can be wrong, Paul as well as the apostles. Let God be the judge of that.

I see nothing wrong with Romans 10:6. Paul seems to using odd logic for sure, but he is getting at the fact that its faith in Jesus that saves, not faith in the Law. That matches up with Christian teachings. Also, even Abraham believed that he would have a son, and his belief was counted to him for righteousness (this was before the law was given in Genesis 15:6).

It's really interesting that you've resorted to name calling. Is that really the attitude of a person doing God's work and spreading the Word of God? Why should i listen to God if his servants insult strangers on the internet trying to have an earnest discussion?

parent.body:
>Genesis 1:26 And God said, Let us make man in our image, after our likeness

Because it's pluralis excellentiae/majestatis and/or inclusive plural (cf. Isaiah 6:8), polytheist. It's also not the act of creation of man, polytheist, but the declaration preceeding it. This is the first time im hearing about lo-ammi, but what i can gather from google is that its a period of time where God rejects the Isreal people and deals with all nations. I'm not sure, but that seems to support Paul in his claim that it's now the time of the gentiles, unless im missing something.

That he was in conflict with Jerusalem means nothing. All people can be wrong, Paul as well as the apostles. Let God be the judge of that.

I see nothing wrong with Romans 10:6. Paul seems to using odd logic for sure, but he is getting at the fact that its faith in Jesus that saves, not faith in the Law. That matches up with Christian teachings. Also, even Abraham believed that he would have a son, and his belief was counted to him for righteousness (this was before the law was given in Genesis 15:6).

It's really interesting that you've resorted to name calling. Is that really the attitude of a person doing God's work and spreading the Word of God? Why should i listen to God if his servants insult strangers on the internet trying to have an earnest discussion?

The Psalms were actually authored by these people and not merely copied, and most of them are probably pseudographical anyway.

Yes, polytheist, one. How perverted do you have to be to lie about a language you don't even speak?

Oh no, polytheists finds plural triads in the scripture they don't even understand. But Gen. 1:27 is explicitly in singular. body:
>Why should i listen to God if his servants insult strangers on the internet trying to have an earnest discussion?

Ok, I apologize for now, and I will try be more charitable and friendly. Ok?

>Mathew 1:23 which is referencing Isaiah 7:14. Well, if you think that it's impossible that a virgin can give birth, then you must also believe that this Isaiah prophesy is wrong, which would mean the Torah is corrupt. If you think virgin birth is possible, then why not Jesus? We know Joseph isn't his father, so...

This is the entire problem. First off, the Torah is only the first five books of Moses. Secondly, this is not a virgin prophecy, nor is that the main issue by any stretch of the imagination. Almah in Hebrew means young woman/maiden. But now to the main issue; this is not a messianic prophecy period! 

Go to Isaiah 7 right now and read it start to finish. It's a prophecy given to king Ahaz during the Syro-Ephraimite war, 8th century BCE. The prophecy is about the fall of the Syro-Ephraimite military alligiance at the hands of Assyria. This would happen and happened when the child the young women carried would reach a certain age of maturity (v.15). It's not about any pagan God-man messiah and the child itself is not the sign, the sign is the fall of Ahaz' enemy kings. It literally can not be misconstrued.

So there you have the first "messianic prophecy" in the NT, and it's a complete fabrication build on misappropriated Hebrew scripture. And according to me, obviously not a part of an original gospel. 

That is literally how the messianic narrative starts off in the NT; with a lie about a pagan God-man messiah, and now you're going to read the entire NT through that perverted lens. And it's not just a misappropriated, fabricated prophecy, it's not just a willful mistranslation -- the Church build upon this narrative. They peddled the theophoric Hebrew personal name Immanuel as some kind of divine title of an incarnate pagan God-man abomination. Churches carry that name all over the world. Theologians, priests, pastors, apologists, all of them have peddled this filthy lie for almost 2000 years. This is *one* single example of a satanic, idolatrous lie peddled by the Church and Christianity, albeit very important in setting the state. Now realize the endless layers of these lies, the endless layers and magnitude of the blasphemies peddled by this satanic imposter entity. That is what Christianity is. 

>I see nothing wrong with Romans 10:6. Paul seems to using odd logic for sure, but he is getting at the fact that its faith in Jesus that saves, not faith in the Law. That matches up with Christian teachings

Pauls is wrong, that is the point. And it's not odd logic, he's turning it on his head. Read the entire song of Moses and you'll understand the context. And Abraham didn't have any Pauline sola fide, he had emunah, ~firmness/faithfulness, he was blessed because he kepts God's commandments and statutes. And of course it "matches" Up with Christian faith, that is literally what it's based on.

Jacob = Israel. It's personification. And the servant is explicitly identified as such. Read the context, not just 53.

>Why should i listen to God if his servants insult strangers on the internet trying to have an earnest discussion?

Ok, I apologize for now, and I will try be more charitable and friendly. Ok?

>Mathew 1:23 which is referencing Isaiah 7:14. Well, if you think that it's impossible that a virgin can give birth, then you must also believe that this Isaiah prophesy is wrong, which would mean the Torah is corrupt. If you think virgin birth is possible, then why not Jesus? We know Joseph isn't his father, so...

This is the entire problem. First off, the Torah is only the first five books of Moses. Secondly, this is not a virgin prophecy, nor is that the main issue by any stretch of the imagination. Almah in Hebrew means young woman/maiden. But now to the main issue; this is not a messianic prophecy period! 

Go to Isaiah 7 right now and read it start to finish. It's a prophecy given to king Ahaz during the Syro-Ephraimite war, 8th century BCE. The prophecy is about the fall of the Syro-Ephraimite military alligiance at the hands of Assyria. This would happen and happened when the child the young women carried would reach a certain age of maturity (v.15). It's not about any pagan God-man messiah and the child itself is not the sign, the sign is the fall of Ahaz' enemy kings. It literally can not be misconstrued.

So there you have the first "messianic prophecy" in the NT, and it's a complete fabrication build on misappropriated Hebrew scripture. And according to me, obviously not a part of an original gospel. 

That is literally how the messianic narrative starts off in the NT; with a lie about a pagan God-man messiah, and now you're going to read the entire NT through that perverted lens. And it's not just a misappropriated, fabricated prophecy, it's not just a willful mistranslation -- the Church build upon this narrative. They peddled the theophoric Hebrew personal name Immanuel as some kind of divine title of an incarnate pagan God-man abomination. Churches carry that name all over the world. Theologians, priests, pastors, apologists, all of them have peddled this filthy lie for almost 2000 years. This is *one* single example of a satanic, idolatrous lie peddled by the Church and Christianity, albeit very important in setting the state. Now realize the endless layers of these lies, the endless layers and magnitude of the blasphemies peddled by this satanic imposter entity. That is what Christianity is. 

>I see nothing wrong with Romans 10:6. Paul seems to using odd logic for sure, but he is getting at the fact that its faith in Jesus that saves, not faith in the Law. That matches up with Christian teachings

Pauls is wrong, that is the point. And it's not odd logic, he's turning it on his head. Read the entire song of Moses and you'll understand the context. And Abraham didn't have any Pauline sola fide, he had emunah, ~firmness/faithfulness, he was blessed because he kepts God's commandments and statutes. And of course it "matches" Up with Christian faith, that is literally what it's based on.
